jalds.alds.ds.tree
Class BinaryTree

java.lang.Object
  jalds.alds.ds.tree.BinaryTree
Direct Known Subclasses:
SimpleBinaryTree
public abstract class BinaryTree
extends java.lang.Object

The keys in a BST are always stored in such a way as to satisfy the BST property. Let x be a ode in the BST, if y is a node in the left subtree key(y) <= key(x) and if y is is a node in the right subtree of x then key(y)>=key(x)

Author:
Devender Gollapally

findSuccessor

public SortableObject findSuccessor(int key)
Find the node with the smallest value greater than the give key, Note the given key must be in the tree i.e A sortable object with the given key must be in the tree

If a node which holds the given key is found and that node has a right child, the successor of this node will be the node with the most min value in the right subtree.

NOTE: findSuccessor will work correctely only if there are no duplicates, if duplicates are allowed it can return back null when you don't expect it.

Parameters:
value -
Returns:
SortableObject

inOrder

public java.util.List<SortableObject> inOrder()
Puts Root in the middle, traversing a binary tree in order will give you a sorted list of elements. Takes O(n) time to make the list, where n is
  • Traverse the left subtree
  • Visit the node
  • Traverse the right subtree

Returns:
a list of Sortable objects collected using In-Order Traversal

preOrder

public java.util.List<SortableObject> preOrder()
Visit the Parent node before left and right subtrees (also know as depth first traversal)
  • Visit the node
  • Traverse the left subtree
  • Traverse the right subtree

Returns:
post ordered list of Sortable Objects

postOrder

public java.util.List<SortableObject> postOrder()
Vist parent after visiting left and right subtrees.
  • Traverse the left subtree
  • Traverse the right subtree
  • Visit the node

Returns:
post order sorted list
